title: Resistive forces - effect of mass on acceleration

content.question: An object falling near Earth’s surface has two forces exerted on it: the gravitational force and a resistive force <math alttext="F sub R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>R</mtext></msub></math> that is proportional to the object’s velocity <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> as <math alttext="F sub R, equals negative k v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>R</mtext></msub><mo> </mo><mo>=</mo><mo> </mo><mo>-</mo><mi>k</mi><mi>v</mi></math>, where <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math> is a positive constant. Does the acceleration of the object depend on its mass? Why or why not?

choices.label: No, because the acceleration is constant and equal to <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>g</mi></math>.
No, because the terminal velocity of the object increases as its mass increases.
Yes, because Newton’s second law indicates that acceleration is inversely proportional to mass.
Yes, because the weight of the object is proportional to its mass, while the resistive force is independent of its mass.

content.answer: Yes, because the weight of the object is proportional to its mass, while the resistive force is independent of its mass.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
